summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting the October 8, 2021, interview of a witness (referred to as [Witness-1]) regarding her experiences working for Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein in Palm Beach, Florida, around 2001-2002. The witness describes being recruited by Maxwell, her duties, the environment at Epstein's home, and sexual misconduct by Epstein during massages.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Recruited the witness for a receptionist job at Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach home, instructed her to bring friends and call a ballet school to find girls, paid her $200/hour, and directed her work.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Lived in the Palm Beach home with Maxwell, was the recipient of massages from the witness during which he was sexually inappropriate, touching her breasts and other body parts.

persons.name: Nicole Young
persons.context: The FBI Special Agent who drafted the 302 form documenting the interview.

persons.name: Sue Tunis
persons.context: The mother in the family the witness was staying with when law enforcement visited to investigate a prostitution ring.

persons.name: [Witness-1]
persons.context: The individual being interviewed. She was a college student recruited by Maxwell to work at Epstein's Palm Beach home around 2001, where she answered phones, shredded books, and gave Epstein massages that involved sexual touching.

connections.description: Described by the witness as living and working together in the Palm Beach home; the witness understood them to be boyfriend and girlfriend.
Maxwell recruited, hired, paid, and directed the work of the witness at Epstein's home.
Epstein was the recipient of massages from the witness and sexually assaulted her during them, touching her breasts and other body parts.
Maxwell explicitly asked the witness to bring friends to the house and had her call a ballet school to find girls, which the witness felt was a recruitment effort.

events.title: Witness recruited and begins work
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell approaches the witness, a college student, and recruits her for a receptionist job at Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach home, offering $200/hour.

events.title: Period of employment and abuse
events.description: The witness works intermittently at Epstein's home for 6-9 months, answering phones, shredding books, and giving Epstein massages during which he sexually assaults her.

events.title: Watches TV coverage of anthrax scare
events.description: The witness recalls being at Epstein's home around the time of the 9/11 attacks, watching TV with Epstein and Maxwell when news broke about anthrax found in West Palm Beach.

events.title: Law enforcement visit and witness leaves
events.description: Law enforcement officers (believed to be a Vice squad) visit the home where the witness is staying (the Tunis family) to investigate a prostitution ring. They ask her to return to Epstein's home to gather information, but she refuses and leaves Palm Beach.

events.title: FBI interview of witness
events.description: The witness is interviewed via video conference by the FBI and Assistant U.S. Attorneys regarding her experiences with Maxwell and Epstein.

locations: Jeffrey Epstein's home in Palm Beach (along the intercostal)
New York, New York (location of interview documentation)
keyFacts: The witness was recruited by Ghislaine Maxwell in 2001 while a student at Palm Beach Atlantic University for a receptionist job at Jeffrey Epstein's home, with an offer of $200 per hour.
During massages she gave to Epstein, he was sexually inappropriate, touching her breasts (over and under her shirt), waist, thighs, and buttocks.
Maxwell instructed the witness to bring friends to the house and to call a local ballet school to find girls, which the witness interpreted as a recruitment effort for Epstein.

The witness's employment ended around 2002 after law enforcement visited a place she was staying to investigate a prostitution ring and asked her to gather information from Epstein's home, which she refused to do.
The witness described a 'phone book' she was instructed to shred, which was cloth-like with a hard black binding, suggesting record-keeping of contacts.
